speaker: Beth
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Beth.

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil. In this episode, we're talking about allergies. Allergies are when a certain food or material makes you feel sick. Do you have any allergies, Beth?

speaker: Beth
text: Yeah, so I am actually allergic to dairy so I can't have anything with milk. So, no cheese, no butter. What about you, Neil? Have you got any allergies?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I'm not great with dairy either, but it's not an allergy – more of an intolerance. So, it just makes me feel a bit bad rather than actually making me sick. But I do have hay fever, so I'm allergic to pollen. That means in the summer months I'm sneezing and coughing all the time. I get runny eyes and a runny nose, and it also gives me a little bit of asthma, so it's a bit of a pain.

speaker: Beth
text: Oh yeah, that sounds really horrible. Now, scientific evidence shows that more people are developing allergies. In this programme we're going to find out about what it's like living with an allergy and where in the world has the highest rate of allergies.

speaker: Neil
text: But first, I have a question for you, Beth. What is the most common allergy in the world? Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a)    Peanuts?

speaker: Neil
text: b)    Pollen? Or

speaker: Neil
text: c)    Dairy?

speaker: Beth
text: I'm going to say pollen. A lot of people I know have hay fever.

speaker: Neil
text: Including me. Well, we'll find out the answer at the end of the show. Now, Beth, you're allergic to dairy, but imagine if you had over 50 allergies. That's the situation for Mia Silverman, who runs a social media account, Allergies with Mia, where she talks about living with lots of allergies.

speaker: Mia Silverman
text: My 50+ allergies include all nuts and their oils. I'm allergic to all fish except for cooked tuna and cooked codfish.

speaker: Beth
text: Life for Mia involves a lot of planning, as she told BBC World Service programme, What in the World.

speaker: call ahead of timeaccommodateprotocols
text: And having these 50+ allergies impacts my life every single day. So, when it comes to going to restaurants: having to call ahead of time, talk to the manager, talk to the chef, make sure that the restaurant can accommodate me, that they can make me something safe and use protocols to prevent any sort of risk of any allergens touching my dish. When it comes to socialising, it can be kind of hard sometimes, because I want to make sure that my friends don't feel inconvenienced or feel like I'm being a burden.

speaker: call ahead of timecall ahead of timecall ahead
text: If Mia wants to go to a restaurant, she has to call ahead of time to tell them about her allergies. If you call ahead of time, you phone somewhere, like a restaurant before you go. We can also say call ahead.

speaker: accommodateAccommodate
text: Mia needs to find out whether restaurants can accommodate her allergies. Accommodate in this context means give someone what they need.

speaker: protocols Protocols
text: Because Mia has so many allergies, she has to visit restaurants which have protocols to stop the food she is allergic to touching her meal. Protocols means a set of rules for a process, to make sure things are done properly.

speaker: Beth
text: Now, most people who have allergies don't have as many as Mia, but scientists believe more people are developing allergies. And there is one place where the number of allergies is particularly high: Australia.

speaker: capital of the worldcapital of the worldcapital of the world
text: In fact, Australia is called the allergy capital of the world. When we describe somewhere as the capital of the world in something, we mean that it is known for that thing. So, the allergy capital of the world is the place in the world with the most allergies.

speaker: Beth
text: BBC journalist Frances Mao is from Australia and explains some of the allergy data to BBC World Service podcast, What in the World.

speaker: capital of the world
text: You're from Australia, which has been called the allergy capital of the world. What is it about Australia in particular that is making people more allergic?

speaker: capital of the worlddrop offor so
text: Australia's termed the allergy capital of the world because, due to the research and the data, that shows that almost one in 10 infants have marked an allergy. And often that's a food allergy or a respiratory allergy. And that does drop off once they're a bit older. Age six or so it goes down to about 6%, and then as an adult it goes down to like 3%.

speaker: drop offdrop off
text: Frances talks about the high numbers of Australian infants, that's babies, who have allergies. But she says the numbers drop off as children get older. If numbers or rates of something drop off, they get lower.

speaker: or so,or so
text: By age six or so, Australian children are less likely to have allergies. We can use or so in informal speech to show that the number is an estimate: it's not exact.

speaker: Neil
text: So Beth, is there anything we can do about all these allergies?

speaker: Beth
text: Well, scientists are investigating giving babies vitamin D, which can be shown to reduce allergies. Another technique is immunotherapy, which involves scientists giving children tiny amounts of the thing they are allergic to and then building up their baby's tolerance.

speaker: Neil
text: Interesting! And I think it's time to find out the answer to my question. I asked you, 'What is the most common allergy in the world?'

speaker: Beth
text: I said pollen. Was I right?

speaker: Neil
text: You were right. Well done!

speaker: call ahead of time
text: OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with call ahead of time, which means to phone somewhere, like a restaurant, before your appointment or before you go there.

speaker: accommodate
text: If you accommodate someone, you give them what they need.

speaker: Protocols
text: Protocols are strict rules for how something is done.

speaker: capital of the worldcapital of the world
text: If somewhere is the capital of the world for a particular thing, it is known for that thing. For example, London is sometimes called the theatre capital of the world because we have lots of theatres.

speaker: drop off
text: If numbers drop off, it means they get lower.

speaker: or so
text: And we can add or so to a number in informal speech to show that the number is an estimate: it's not exact.
